did.head: Descriptive Summary

repository.label: Repository
repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

did.physloc: For current information on the location of these materials, please consult the Library's online catalog.
did.abstract: William E. Phillips was an executive and chairman of Ogilvy & Mather and Ogilvy Group advertising agencies.
The William E. Phillips Papers span the years 1969-2001 and include writings, speeches and printed materials that document Phillips' career with Ogilvy & Mather.

accessrestrict.head: Access Restrictions
accessrestrict.p: Researchers must register and agree to copyright and privacy laws before using this collection.
All or portions of this collection may be housed off-site in Duke University's Library Service Center. There may be a 48-hour delay in obtaining these materials.
Please contact Research Services staff before visiting the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library to use this collection.

userestrict.head: Copyright Notice
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], William E. Phillips Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The William E. Phillips Papers were received by the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library as a gift in 2003.

bioghist.head: Biographical Note

chronitem.event: Chairman and CEO, Ogilvy & Mather Worldwide

bioghist.p: Phillips is also past chairman of Outward Bound's International Board, and has served as director for several firms, including Sunglass Hut and Lillian Vernon.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The William E. Phillips Papers span the years 1969-2001 and include writings, speeches and printed materials that document Phillips' career with the Ogilvy & Mather advertising agency.

The collection is arranged into two categories of materials: Printed Materials, and Writings and Speeches. Phillips writings and speeches cover a wide range of themes, but he was particularly concerned with improving client-agency relations, agency creativity and productivity, and community involvement.

Related Materials: Related materials pertaining to the Ogilvy & Mather agency may be found in the Edgar Hatcher Papers, the Jock Elliott Papers, the Robert S. Smith Papers, the David B. McCall Papers, and in the J. Walter Thompson Company Advertising Vertical Files.

controlaccess.head: Subject Headings
controlaccess.p: These are searchable subject entries for this collection. Performing a search on these subjects in the Duke University Libraries online catalog will bring up other related research materials.

item.corpname: John W. Hartman Center for Sales, Advertising & Marketing History

did.unittitle: Ogilvy & Mather and Ogilvy Group printed materials, 1980-1990

scopecontent.p: Arranged alphabetically, and therein chronologically by date of publication.
Publication of Ogilvy & Mather. Phillips wrote articles for several issues.

unittitle.title: Why Business Must Support the Arts,
Why Your Advertising Agency Needs a Better Product,
Better Creativity and Adequate Compensation: The Keys to Advertising Productivity in the '80s,
Last 50-plus Year--Plus Some Predictions on Commercial Communications and the Importance of Brands,
Need for a Youth Service Corps,

scopecontent.p: Remarks written by David Ogilvy, read by Phillips, with introduction and comments also by Phillips.

unittitle.title: Speaking the Same Language Does Not Always Mean Thinking the Same--The Anglo-American Paradox,
Strategy is What the Boss Wants to Do,
Training: The Heart and Soul of Your Future,
Underneath the Iceberg; or, How O&M Grabbed the Hershey Bar,
Why Your Advertising Agency Needs a Better Product,
You Can't Afford Not to Get the Most Out of Your Agency,
